item.title: Wenona add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "There are books of which the backs and covers are by far the best parts." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "Although a skillful flatterer is a most delightful companion if you have him all to yourself, his taste becomes very doubtful when he takes to complimenting other people." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "No one who can read, ever looks at a book, even unopened on a shelf, like one who cannot." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "No one is useless in this world who lightens the burdens of another." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "Procrastination is the thief of time, collar him." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I do not want people to be very agreeable, as it saves me the trouble of liking them a great deal." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "From the very beginning— from the first moment, I may almost say— of my acquaintance with you, your manners, impressing me with the fullest belief of your arrogance, your conceit, and your selfish disdain of the feelings of others, were such as to form the groundwork of disapprobation on which succeeding events have built so immovable a dislike; and I had not known you a month before I felt that you were the last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "You pierce my soul. I am half agony, half hope...I have loved none but you." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Mary wished to say something very sensible, but knew not how." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Better be without sense than misapply it as you do. " -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I am excessively diverted. " -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "That will do extremely well, child. You have delighted us long enough. Let the other young ladies have time to exhibit." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Badly done, Emma!" -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "A man does not recover from such devotion of the heart to such a woman! He ought not; he does not." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "A report of a most alarming nature reached me two days ago." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be a fool." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "Outside of a dog, a book is man's best friend. Inside of a dog it's too dark to read." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: Wenona add a quote by A.A. Milne
Wenona add a quote by Benjamin Franklin
item.description: "How many observe Christ's birthday! How few, His precepts!" -- Benjamin Franklin

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description:
"I can listen no longer in silence. I must speak to you by such means as are within my reach. You pierce my soul. I am half agony, half hope. Tell me not that I am too late, that such precious feelings are gone for ever. I offer myself to you again with a heart even more your own than when you almost broke it, eight years and a half ago. Dare not say that man forgets sooner than woman, that his love has an earlier death. I have loved none but you. Unjust I may have been, weak and resentful I have been, but never inconstant. You alone have brought me to Bath. For you alone, I think and plan. Have you not seen this? Can you fail to have understood my wishes? I had not waited even these ten days, could I have read your feelings, as I think you must have penetrated mine. I can hardly write. I am every instant hearing something which overpowers me. You sink your voice, but I can distinguish the tones of that voice when they would be lost on others. Too good, too excellent creature! You do us justice, indeed. You do believe that there is true attachment and constancy among men. Believe it to be most fervent, most undeviating, in F. W.
I must go, uncertain of my fate; but I shall return hither, or follow your party, as soon as possible. A word, a look, will be enough to decide whether I enter your father's house this evening or never." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "but for my own part, if a book is well written, I always find it too short." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Run mad as often as you choose, but do not faint!" -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "It is not everyone,' said Elinor, 'who has your passion for dead leaves." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "There are people, who the more you do for them, the less they will do for themselves." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jude Deveraux
item.description: "My soul will find yours." -- Jude Deveraux

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Gabriel García Márquez
item.description: "He dug so deeply into her sentiments that in search of interest he found love, because by trying to make her love him he ended up falling in love with her. Petra Cotes, for her part, loved him more and more as she felt his love increasing, and that was how in the ripeness of autumn she began to believe once more in the youthful superstition that poverty was the servitude of love. Both looked back then on the wild revelry, the gaudy wealth, and the unbridled fornication as an annoyance and they lamented that it had cost them so much of their lives to find the paradise of shared solitude. Madly in love after so many years of sterile complicity, they enjoyed the miracle of living each other as much at the table as in bed, and they grew to be so happy that even when they were two worn-out people they kept on blooming like little children and playing together like dogs." -- Gabriel García Márquez

item.title: Wenona add a quote by C.L. Wilson
item.description: "My beloved is the sun And I am the earth that thrives only in her warmth. My beloved is the rain And I am the grass that thirsts for her quenching kiss. My beloved is the wind And I am the wings that soar when she fills me with her gentle strength. My beloved is the rock Upon which rests the happiness of all my days. —The Elements of Love, a poem by Aileron v'En Kavali of the Fey" -- C.L. Wilson

item.title: Wenona add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of man; but this would be nothing if you really liked him." -- Jane Austen
